botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Contact with sap may irritate skin and all parts may cause stomach upset if ingested. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Alocasia are robust evergreen rhizomatous or tuberous perennials with large, usually peltate, leaves with conspicuous veins; insignificant flowering spathes may be followed by orange-red fruits

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow indoors in a potting mixture of equal parts of composted bark, loam and sand, in filtered light. Water freely in the growing season, provide high humidity by placing container on a tray of moist gravel or pebbles and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser every 2-3 weeks. Water moderately in winter. Requires a minimum temperature of 15-18°C. Can be planted outside after frost, or started off in pots under glass in late winter to early spring. Plant bulbs so their growing tip is just above the soil surface, water sparingly initially then keep moist during the growing season and lift bulbs in autumn before the first frosts; keep tubers dry and frost free throughout winter
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division in spring or summer. Propagate by stem cuttings in spring
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to glasshouse red spider mite and mealybugs
